Jacob B. Crist to Abraham Lincoln, 12 June 18481 Having a little money on hand for the Colonization Society and not finding it convenient

to procure and Eastern draft I have just deposited fifty dollars in the hands of your friendJudge Logan, subject to your order, you will greatly oblige me by paying the above amounttotheof $50.00to the order of RevWmMcLainSecyAm Col Society.2 Judge Logan & his competitionMajor Harrisare now both in town and will address the people of thiscountythis afternoon from the stump. The Judge’s election is of coursecertain.3TheWhigsare well satisfied with the nomination ofGenlTaylor.4The wheat crop in thisstatewill be extraordinarily good. The general health of this county is very good.

The Judge’s election is of coursecertain.3TheWhigsare well satisfied with the nomination ofGenlTaylor.4The wheat crop in thisstatewill be extraordinarily good. The general health of this county is very good.
citations: The African Repository and Colonial Journal24 (September 1848), 288.

Michael Burlingame,Abraham Lincoln: A Life(Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press, 2008), 1:271; Howard W. Allen and
                     Vincent A. Lacey, eds.,Illinois Elections, 1818-1990(Carbondale and Edwardsville: Southern Illinois University Press, 1992), 8, 126.

footnotes.text:
1Jacob B. Crist wrote this entire letter, including the address on the last sheet,
                  which was folded to make an envelope.

2Crist is referring in the first line to the Illinois Colonization Society.  Lincoln’s
                  donation was one of two coming from Illinois to the American Colonization Society
                  between July and September 1848.The African Repository and Colonial Journal24 (September 1848), 288.

3Stephen T. Logan and Thomas L. Harris vied to replace Lincoln, who did not receive
                  the Whig Party’s nomination for another term, as representative  from the Seventh
                  Congressional District. In August 1848, Logan would lose to Harris in a close race.Michael Burlingame,Abraham Lincoln: A Life(Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press, 2008), 1:271; Howard W. Allen and
                     Vincent A. Lacey, eds.,Illinois Elections, 1818-1990(Carbondale and Edwardsville: Southern Illinois University Press, 1992), 8, 126.

4Reference to the Whig  National Convention’s nomination of Zachary Taylor for president
                  in the1848 presidential election.
